# Introduction

On October 10, 2020, then Presidential candidate Joe Biden's campaign team aired an advertisement touting the former Vice President's national security credentials. This particular advertisement is narrated by a man identified as Jim, an "Iraq War Veteran," who, with a personal touch, describes the efforts of the former Vice President in delivering Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) vehicles to Iraq and Afghanistan. These vehicles were known for their heavy armor, which likely saved the lives and limbs of servicemen and women who were deployed at the time to the Middle East. The advertisement was later pulled by the Biden Campaign after a retired Army Lieutenant General, Sean MacFarland, objected to the advertisement on the grounds that the ad used images of him without his consent [@moore_biden_2020]. The images in question showed then Lieutenant General MacFarland, in uniform, shaking hands with Biden as the former Vice President arrived to Iraq [@moore_biden_2020]. 

In objecting to the ad, MacFarland noted that he had not granted permission to the Biden Campaign to use images which featured the general in such a recognizable manner. Further, MacFarland expressed concern that voters would assume that his appearance in the ad constituted an endorsement of Biden, and noted that, "A number of people have understandably inferred that my appearance [in this Biden Campaign advertisement] constitutes an endorsement of the former Vice President. It does not. To be clear, I have not endorsed President Trump, either. I object to the use of ANY military personnel in uniform in political ads - full stop" [MacFarland quoted in @moore_biden_2020]. 

This incident illustrates one of the many ways in which political candidates use the military, especially during elections.^[To be clear, President Trump's campaign likewise used military symbols and imagery in many advertisements. For a salient example in which the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff appeared in one of Trump's advertisements, see @seligman_top_2020.] While civilians have long appealed to the public by harnessing the popularity of the military or of individual military figures in a variety of ways, the practice of doing so during a closely contested election season underscores how a non-partisan institution can find itself - willingly, or in the case of MacFarland, unwillingly - thrust into the political spotlight.   

This chapter examines variation in the use of the military during Presidential campaign television advertisements. The content of campaign advertisements is primarily the purview of civilian rather than military actors, and thus, examining this particular form of behavior in depth will facilitate a comparison between political behaviors undertaken by military actors (the focus of last chapter) vice civilian actors. Of interest is whether any discernible variation can be detected in the degree to which civilian actors have used the military in ways that violate the principles of civil-military relations, and to account for this variation. 

This chapter proceeds in four parts. First, this chapter briefly revisits the theory argued previously in this dissertation, which posits that the levels of political polarization and the prestige of the military impact the degree to which military and civilian actors adhere to the central principles of civil-military relations. In the second part of the chapter, I present the methodology and the data used in this chapter, which include roughly 3,600 presidential campaign television advertisements aired on behalf of the five elections occurring inclusively from 2000 - 2016. With the exception of some of the data that is missing, these advertisements comprise all presidential campaign television advertisements used in these elections.^[So far as I know, this dissertation chapter comprises the only scholarly effort undertaken with this particular data for the purposes of coding the use of military symbols, actors, and behaviors.]

The third part of the chapter explores and analyzes the data in detail. The analysis first explores variation in the types of military imagery that have been featured in campaign advertisements, and then explores variation in the ways that various military actors have committed expressly partisan acts during these advertisements, such as endorsing or attacking a political candidate. The results show that there is significant variation in how civilians have used the military, to include its symbols and actors, in presidential campaign television advertisements over the time period examined. Furthermore, the results provide moderately strong support for the notion that the level of military prestige drives the choice of civilians to use the military in ways that challenge one or more of the central principles of civil-military relations, and especially the principle of non-partisanship. In the fourth and final part of the chapter, I conclude by integrating the results of this chapter with the results obtained in the previous chapter. I also lay the groundwork and motivate the qualitative case studies which begin in the subsequent chapter. 

# A Brief Review of the Theory

In this section of the chapter, I briefly review the theory presented earlier in chapter two of this dissertation. I will not review in detail the three central principles of civil-military relations, as these have been covered in depth in the previous two chapters. Instead, the next several paragraphs will focus on a review of the theoretical expectation that the level of military prestige _may_ impact the willingness of _both_ civilian and military leaders to behave in ways that fail to adhere to the central principles of civil-military relations. 

The level of military prestige, I argued in chapter two, is one of two independent variables that shape the constraining influence of the three central principles of civil-military relations, which include the principle of civilian control of the military, the principle of non-partisanship of the military institution, and the principle of non-interference of the military into certain realms of state politics. I argued that high levels of military prestige present military and civilian actors with _opportunities_ to involve the military in politics, and thus, when military prestige is high, civilian and military actors are more likely to engage in behaviors that violate these central principles. 

The other independent variable that impacts the political behavior of civilian or military actors, I argued in chapter two, is the level of political polarization. I argued in chapter two that rising political polarization provides a "motive" for military actors in particular to intervene in politics, and thus, when polarization is high relative to when it is low, military actors are increasingly likely to engage in behaviors that violate the central principles of civil-military relations. 

## The Impact of Military Prestige on Military and Civilian Leaders

Chapter two argued that the level of military prestige is important because higher levels of military prestige increase the _potential_ that the military be used, either by civilian or military actors, to impact public opinion. This central claim arose mainly from the political communication literature about political elites, which argues that the public often looks to elites who are considered or believed by the public to be "knowledgeable" and "trustworthy" [@lupia_democratic_1998, 69-76] when forming decisions or opinions [@zaller_nature_1992]. 

Chapter two noted that although this and other literature on elite communication [@saunders_no_2017; @guisinger_mapping_2017; @baum_relationships_2008] is not specifically written from the perspective of military leaders in particular, applying this literature to military leaders and military elites in particular seems plausible, especially when the variable of military prestige is conceptualized as a relational indicator of the overall level of trust and confidence placed by the public in the military. Chapter two argued for a broad definition of the variable military prestige, and noted that several different pathways might ultimately impact the level of prestige of a military, including defeat or victory in war, and an overall assessment of how central or important the military is thought to be by the nation. The point of doing so was to allow room for the level of military prestige to change as a result of multiple possible factors. Regardless of how it changes, chapter two argued that when the public trusts and respects the military and its leaders at relatively high levels, it is reasonable to conclude that the public simultaneously perceives the military and its leaders as possessing the traits of knowledge and trustworthiness, and thus, as the prestige of the military rises, it is increasingly likely that the public _may_ also listen or become persuaded by the military and its leaders. 

Chapter two also emphasized that the _potential_ to impact public opinion is different from the actual _ability_ or _efficacy_ of the military to impact public opinion, as several experimental studies have shown [@golby_military_2012; @golby_listening_2013]. For the purposes of this dissertation, it is the belief of civilian and military actors in the _potential_ of the military to impact public opinion when the level of military prestige is relatively high that matters, and not whether a more prestigious military actually can and does persuade the public to a greater degree.   

The theory also explained in chapter two that military and civilian leaders both become aware of the military's increasing potential to move public opinion as the prestige of the military rises. In terms of how this impacts civilian and military actor behavior, an important question then becomes what type of outcome civilian and military actors may seek to influence. Civilian leaders, whose goal is to stay in political power or to achieve their desired policy choices, become increasingly willing to violate one or more of the principles of civil-military relations, and therefore to engage in a political behavior or activity that does so. Military leaders, too, may be more willing to behave in ways that violate one or more of the central principles of civil-military relations as the military institution becomes more prestigious. Chapter two also articulated a number of forms or types of behaviors that civilian and military actors engage in that, depending on the context in which these behaviors occur, violate one or more of the central principles of civil-military relations. These included, for example, the civilian actor behaviors of _electoral swaggering_, _partisan stacking_ and _the military as sales reps_, and the military actor behaviors of _explicit insubordination_, _running for office_, and what Risa Brooks has called "politicking" and "shoulder tapping" [@brooks_militaries_2009, 219]. The theory strongly advocated for evaluating each of these and many other types of political behaviors engaged in by civilian and military actors through the lens of their impact to the three central principles of civil-military relations. 

In summary, chapter two argued that rising military prestige presents an _opportunity_ for civilian and military actors to use the military to sway the public. Depending on what policy outcomes or issues civilian and military actors seek to influence - whether it is an election, or a use of force decision - this can result in civilian and military leaders engaging in political behaviors that challenge the principles of civilian control, non-partisanship, and non-interference of the military institution. When civilian and military leaders believe that the military is highly prestigious and therefore capable of swaying the public, both actor types, on the whole, are less likely to adhere to and thus, be constrained by, the central principles of civil-military relations. Combined with the presence (or absence) of a high level of military prestige, which affords military actors with a "motive" to engage in political behaviors that violate the principles of civil-military relations, chapter two argued that in total, four possible domestic structures emerge, each of which corresponds to distinct patterns of political activity that involve the military. 

# Methodology

In order to examine potential variation in the political behaviors undertaken by civilian actors that involve the military, we must examine a behavior that is primarily the purview of civilian actors. Such an approach parallels the approach implemented in the previous chapter, which explored retired military officer opinion commentary, a political behavior that, I argued, is undertaken primarily by military actors. This chapter examines the civilian use of the military in campaign advertisements, a form of behavior that most approximates the civilian actor behavior of _Electoral Swaggering_ that was described previously in chapter two. 

In this chapter, I examine all of the presidential campaign advertisements that aired on television in the five elections that occurred between 2000 and 2016, inclusively, which amount to roughly 3,600 campaign ads in total. During this period, the level of US military prestige, as measured by Gallup polling that tracks the percentage of the public that has a "great deal or quite a lot" of trust in the military, ranges from 64 (in 2000) to 82 (in 2003 and 2009) [@noauthor_confidence_2020].^[In the years that presidential elections occur, the lowest value is 64 (2000) and the highest is 75 (2004 and 2012), however.] 

To be clear, this does not by itself constitute quite the degree of variation that a researcher hopes for, but there are other things that can and should be leveraged. First, from a qualitative perspective, this period captures (albeit barely) the significant change in the international environment marked by the attacks on the United States that occurred on September 11, 2001. These attacks were the proximate cause of two wars that the US military fought beginning that same year. Notwithstanding any debates about its effectiveness during these conflicts, the continual deployment of the US military to Iraq and Afghanistan likely increased the prestige of the military in a sense that may not be entirely captured by the Gallup polling data.

Additionally, when we also factor in the credibility ratings of other predominant political institutions, a greater shift in what we might call "relative" military prestige becomes slightly more evident. For example, the gap between the percentage of Americans surveyed who expressed a "great deal or quite a lot" in the military compared to Congress was 40% (in favor of the military) in 2000 and 64% (also in favor of the military) in 2016. The percentage of surveyed Americans who placed a "great deal or quite a lot" of trust in the military, Congress, and the gap between these two measures (the "relative" level of military prestige) is displayed in Figure \@ref(fig:trust-ch4). 

```{r trust-ch4, warning=FALSE, echo=FALSE, include=TRUE, fig.height=4, fig.width=6, fig.cap = "Public Trust in the US Military, Congress, 2000 - 2021"}

df_trust_ch4 <- read_csv(here("data","inst-trust-ch4.csv")) %>% print()

df_trust_consolidated_ch4 <- df_trust_ch4 %>% 
  mutate(Rel_Mil_Pres=Military-Congress) %>% pivot_longer(Congress:Rel_Mil_Pres, names_to = "Value", values_to = "Score") %>% distinct () %>% print()

df_trust_consolidated_ch4 %>% ggplot(aes(x=Year, y=Score, color=Value)) + geom_smooth(se=FALSE) + labs(x="Year", y="Percentage Surveyed Expressing\n A Great Deal or Quite a Lot of\n Confidence In...", subtitle="Data Available from 'Confidence in Institutions,'\n https://news.gallup.com/poll/1597/Confidence-Institutions.aspx") + scale_color_discrete(name="Level of Trust",
                         breaks=c("Congress", "Military",  "Rel_Mil_Pres"),
                         labels=c("Congress", "The Military","Difference Between Congress and the Military")) + theme(legend.position="bottom") + 
  geom_vline(xintercept=2001, size=.2, colour="tomato") + 
  geom_vline(xintercept=2009, size=.2, colour="dodgerblue") +
  geom_vline(xintercept=2017, size=.2, colour="tomato") +
  geom_text(aes(x=2000, label="Bush 43",y=17), colour="tomato", angle=90, vjust=1, text=element_text(size=9)) + 
  geom_text(aes(x=2008, label="Obama",y=30), colour="dodgerblue", angle=90, vjust=1, text=element_text(size=9)) + 
  geom_text(aes(x=2016, label="Trump",y=30), colour="tomato", angle=90, vjust=1, text=element_text(size=9))   
```

At the very least, the period from 2000 to 2016 generally saw relative increases in the prestige of the military. These increases are small when we consider trust in the military in its raw form, but larger when viewed in relative terms compared to Congress. Both measurements may be useful when exploring the impact of military prestige on the civilian propensity to use the military in presidential campaign advertisements in ways that violate the central principles of civil-military relations. 

Polarization over the same period also generally increased, except for measurements of affective polarization that rely on measurements provided by American National Election Survey, which show a dip in affective polarization between 2016 [@jeffrey_b_lewis_voteview_2020; @noauthor_american_nodate; @iyengar_affect_2012]. In short, the time period examined in this chapter, 2000 - 2016, broadly reflects movement between a domestic environment characterized by moderate polarization and moderate military prestige to one marked by higher polarization and higher military prestige. Because both of the independent variables of polarization and military prestige are changing over this time period, the statistical analysis will enable us to better disentangle the relative impacts of these (and other) variables. 

## Civilian Use of Military Imagery and Actors in Campaign Ads

Examining how civilians have featured the military in the content of campaign advertisements provides several advantages from a research perspective that are worth briefly articulating. The first is that, similar to the behavior of retired military officer opinion commentary, there is no _a priori_ expectation that featuring a military image or a military actor in a presidential campaign advertisement must violate, or automatically violates, one or more principles of civil-military relations. In fact, there is no expectation that civilian candidates choose to feature the military in campaign advertisements over and above any other institution, or over any other topic in general. Civilian political candidates and their campaign teams have an almost limitless array of options when producing campaign ads. 

A second significant advantage afforded by examining campaign advertisements is that they comprise an integral part of the democratic process. Like other democracies, the United States holds elections at fixed intervals, and thus, we can expect campaign advertisements to regularly occur in periods leading up to an election. We can and should also expect that the content of campaign ads will likely change over time, and for a variety of factors. The issues that are important to voters are not static, and the broad political atmosphere changes over time. Of course, we would expect civilian political candidates and their campaign teams to construct advertisements around those issues and topics they think will be most effective in persuading the public so as to secure electoral victory. At times, perhaps when wars are fought, for example, we might expect advertisements to feature the military in some noticeable way. While we cannot predict what specific issues will be on the docket four or eight years from now, we can suspect, if the theory offered earlier in this dissertation is accurate, that changes in the relative level of military prestige _could_ impact the degree to which civilian candidates feature or showcase the military in the content of campaign advertisements. 

How might civilian actors fail to adhere to the central principles of civil-military relations through the content of campaign advertisements? It is unlikely that the content of a campaign advertisement would violate the principle of civilian control. This is because, as has been stated earlier in this dissertation, civilians have a responsibility to maintain and enforce the principle of civilian control, but usually do not expressly violate the principle through acts they commit. Rather, civilian behavior "erodes" the principle of civilian control when civilians excessively defer to the military such that civilians no longer adequately influence the policy making process [@beliakova_erosion_2021]. Thus, a campaign advertisement that uses the military in such a way that violates the principle of civilian control would take on a rather extreme form, perhaps if an advertisement featured a retired military actor urging others to mount a coup or stage some other act of obvious insubordination. 

It is far more likely that featuring the military in television campaign advertisements would break the other two principles of civilian control - the principle of non-partisanship and non-interference of the military. A violation of the principle of non-partisanship of the military vis-a-vis campaign advertisements would occur if an advertisement clearly intimated that the military favored or endorsed a particular candidate, or the policies or political stances of a candidate, or a particular political party over another. Such a message, deliberate or not, could and likely would communicate to the American public that the military (or a faction of the military, or particular leaders within the military) favors a particular political entity over another. Examples of such behavior abound in almost every election, as this chapter will show. 

A violation of the principle of "non-interference" of the military into certain realms of state policy might occur if a campaign advertisement featured a military actor weighing in on policy arenas that are largely disconnected from national security, defense, and other essential roles the military is expected to fill in American society [@ben-meir_civil-military_1995]. Hypothetically speaking, this could occur if a retired general appeared in a campaign advertisement and spoke predominantly about a candidate's plan to reform social security or to reduce the national debt, and why particular candidate's plans to tackle these topics are more sound than another candidate's plans on the same topics. In this example, it would be reasonable to conclude that the advertisement violated the principle of non-interference because the retired military officer is likely not an expert on the topics of social security reform and the national debt. I do not question that a large number of reasonably intelligent retired military officers, like many retired individuals at large within American society, are smart and can understand the topics of social security reform and reigning in national debt. At issue, though, in this hypothetical example, is the choice by the civilian candidate or campaign team to use a military figure to convince the American public of the candidate's merits on these particular topics. It is doubtful that a retired general, admiral, colonel, or captain are truly the most qualified experts to weigh the candidates' stances over these issues that are somewhat removed from topics that distinctly involve national security, and thus, such an act violates the principle of non-interference. 

## Hypotheses Explored in this Chapter

The five hypotheses presented in chapter two are listed below. Given that this chapter focuses on a type of political undertaken primarily by civilian actors, this chapter primarily addresses H3. It will not address H1, which was addressed in the previous chapter, nor H2, as both of these hypotheses are addressed towards military rather than civilian actors. This chapter will, however, inform H4 and H5.  

H1: Military actors increasingly violate the central principles of civil-military relations when polarization is high relative to periods of low polarization. 

H2: Military actors increasingly violate the central principles of civil-military relations in public and visible ways when military prestige is high relative to periods of low military prestige. 

H3: Civilian actors increasingly violate the central principles of civil-military relations when military prestige is high relative to periods of low military prestige. 

H4: Military and civilian actors engage in relatively more visible and public forms of political behavior that involve the military institution when military prestige is high relative to periods of low military prestige. 

H5: The most extreme levels of overall political activity occur in environments that are characterized by simultaneously high levels of political polarization and military prestige. 

## The Data

The data consist of all (more than 3,600) presidential campaign television advertisements from the 2000 - 2016 presidential elections. ^[Unfortunately, the raw data used to code the 1996 election is no longer available to review; hence, this study begins with the 2000 Presidential Election. Additionally, raw data for the 2020 Election is not available at the time of this writing, but is projected to become available sometime in late 2022 or 2023.] The data is made available from the Wisconsin Advertising Project (WiscAD) and Wesleyan Media Project (WMP). For the 2000, 2004, and 2008 elections, the data come from the WiscAd, and consist of individual PDF documents that contain a full transcript and several still images of the advertisement [@goldstein_political_2002; @goldstein_presidential_2007; @goldstein_presidential_2011]. For 2012 and 2016 elections, the data comes from the WMP, and consists of full motion video, to include sound [@fowler_presidential_2017; @fowler_presidential_2020].^[See the Appendix for further details regarding how the data was cleaned and merged to enable a comparison over time.]

In the statistical analysis portion of this chapter, I also rely on data covering polarization, military prestige, and military casualties. For polarization data, I primarily rely on DW-Nominate (dynamic-weight, three step estimation) scores, which are constructed using roll-call voting data from the US House of Representatives and the US Senate [@lewis_voteview_nodate]. I also include "affective" polarization measurements, which are generally constructed using a series of "feeling thermometer" scores from the American National Election Study (ANES) [@iyengar_affect_2012; @iyengar_strengthening_2018; @iyengar_origins_2019].  

As a proxy for military prestige, I rely on Gallup public opinion data that captures the level of trust that Americans have placed in the military and a variety of other institutions over the past several decades [@noauthor_confidence_2020]. Finally, I use a variety of open source data sources from the Department of Defense regarding US military casualties to measure levels of hostile casualties sustained by US military forces over the past several decades.^[These sources include @department_of_defense_dcas_2011; @department_of_defense_dcas_2021; @department_of_defense_dcas_2021-1; @department_of_defense_dcas_2021-2; @department_of_defense_dcas_2021-3; @department_of_defense_dcas_2021-4; @department_of_defense_dcas_2021-5; @department_of_defense_dmdc_2021.]  

After gathering the data, I implement an empirical strategy that at its root, looks to answer two major questions. The first question, does this particular advertisement have any type of military image or symbol featured in the advertisement? At a minimum, answering this first question will help paint a picture regarding how frequently military imagery generally appears in campaign advertisements. The second question I seek to answer is whether a particular advertisement features the military in some way that violates the principles of civil-military relations. Answering these two main questions and presenting the results in a meaningful way is the aim of th next section of this chapter. 

# Analysis

```{r data, include=FALSE, echo=FALSE}

summary(df_campaign_ads_read)

# rename the variable 'missing' to 'missing_ad', and replace all N/A values of 'missing_ad' with #0

df_campaign_ads_raw <- df_campaign_ads_read [1:3666,] %>% select(year:missing) %>% rename(missing_ad=missing) %>% mutate_at(
  .vars = vars(missing_ad), 
  .funs = ~ case_when(is.na(.) ~ 0, TRUE ~1) 
) %>% view()

# create another, identical data frame for conducting MICE later
df_campaign_ads_raw_mice <- df_campaign_ads_raw


```

In this portion of the chapter, I analyze the data and present the results. First, I present and analyze the general frequency and type of military symbols and imagery that appear within and across the data. This first step is meant to serve as a more general overview of the ways in which the military appears - in some fashion - in campaign advertisements over time.  Second, I analyze the frequency with which particular campaign advertisements involve the military in ways that violate one or more of the principles of civil-military relations. This second step is the more substantive of the two in terms of examining which factors impact the degree to which civilian actors violate the principles of civil-military relations.     

In total, the data consist of 3,666 advertisements across the five presidential elections that occurred from 2000 - 2016, inclusively. 89 of these observations (2.4%) are missing.^[After contacting WiscAd and WMP, there is no reason to suspect that the data is not missing at random. Later in the statistical analysis, I conduct multiple imputation to deal with the missing data, but want to first provide the "raw" or "as is" facts given the data that is available.] After cleaning and merging the data across the several data sets, I capture several variables that WiscAd and WMP have already coded for that may be helpful for the statistical analysis conducted later in this chapter. These variables, and a short description of each, are displayed in Table \@ref(tab:existing-variables).

I then develop four dichotomous variables that capture various types of military images and symbols.^[I came up with these four variables myself by first viewing approximately 250 advertisements across the five data sets to determine what categories would be most meaningful in terms of distinguishing the different types of images and symbols.] These four variables denote the use of active duty US soldiers or troops, veterans, combat, or US military hardware. 

The first kind of military imagery, that of US soldiers or troops, include images of US servicemen and women who are in uniform. It could include a lone soldier saluting, or thousands of US servicemen and women training, or a host of other possible scenarios. The key thing I look for are images of US military uniforms, military medals, or insignia that clearly denote US soldiers. The second type of military imagery relates to veterans, which I consider distinct from images of troops. This indicator variable looks for any image of a veteran, which could include gatherings of veterans, such as an American Legion or Veterans of Foreign Wars group, or imagery of a wounded veteran recovering in a hospital, or a veteran, for example, who is in a wheelchair during a later stage of life.

The third indicator accounts for images of combat. This could include things such as an explosion, a soldier driving a tank, or a scene containing fighting that clearly depicts US soldiers involved. This category does not include images of fighting that clearly involve non-US soldiers, such as soldiers of a foreign military or members of a terrorist group. The fourth indicator variable for a type of military imagery accounts for images of US military hardware. This variable captures advertisements that contain images or scenes of any major military hardware item, such as a naval vessel, fighter jet, or military radar system. 

I allow for the possibility that an advertisement portrays or includes more than one type of imagery. Again, the purpose of each of these four variables is to obtain a general idea for the prevalence of military imagery across the data. These four variables do not necessarily indicate that a campaign advertisement has violated any of the central principles of civil-military relations. 

Finally, I develop four additional variables that measure several other items of interest. These include the overall purpose of the advertisement, whether the candidate is a veteran, whether the advertisement explicitly mentions or portrays that the featured candidate is a veteran, and whether the advertisement itself is entirely focused on military, defense, veteran, and/or or national security issues. These variables, the question they intend to answer, and the potential range of values these variables can take, are displayed in Table \@ref(tab:el-ads-additional).

### The Prominence of Military Imagery in US Presidential Elections

Table \@ref(tab:desc-stats) shows that 15 percent of the presidential campaign television ads featured military imagery of some kind. The least and most saturated elections in terms of military imagery, respectively, were the 2000 and 2004 elections, when 6.5% and 20.9% of advertisements featured some kind of military imagery.^[The 2000 Election contains the highest incidence of missing data, at 11.2%. Still, it is very unlikely that the 2000 Election is _not_ the least saturated with military imagery. For the 2000 Election to eclipse the second-least saturated election (2012), at least 18 of the 39 missing ads (46%) from the 2000 Election would have to contain military imagery. As the data is missing randomly, this is certainly possible, but very highly unlikely.] Following the 2004 Election, the percentage of campaign ads containing military imagery declined in the 2008 and 2012 Elections before rising sharply again in 2016. 

There are a number of possible explanations behind these broad trends. One involves the arc of American foreign policy, and the military's role in shaping it between 2000 and 2016. The September 11, 2001 attacks ushered in a distinct role for the military as the US conducted lengthy military operations, first in Afghanistan in 2001 and later in Iraq in 2003. That military imagery contained high relative proportions of military imagery during the 2004 and 2008 Elections is mostly unsurprising. The war in Iraq was a major theme in the 2004 Election, when the incumbent, George W. Bush, ran against the Democratic challenger, John Kerry, a decorated combat veteran of the Vietnam War. At the time of the 2008 election, the surge of US military forces in Iraq had shown signs that it was likely working to at least alleviate the level of sectarian violence in Iraq. Moreover, US casualties, after peaking in 2007, had also been declining steadily throughout 2008 [@us_department_of_defense_dcas_2021]. This is likely a major reason why the proportion of campaign ads featuring military imagery declined in 2008 relative to the proportion of ads featuring military imagery in the 2004 election. 

The arc of US foreign policy, and the US military's role in it, becomes a bit more complicated from 2008 to 2016. First, from 2008 to 2012, the US' involvement in Iraq ended, but its involvement in Afghanistan increased. Indeed, the last of US forces withdrew from Iraq at the end of 2011 when Operation _New Dawn_ concluded.^[US forces would return to Iraq as part of the counter-ISIS effort several years later, and they remain there, albeit in relatively small numbers, as of writing this dissertation in early 2022.] But, President Barack Obama has also in 2009 decided to increase the number of US forces in Afghanistan as part of a surge of US forces in order to conduct a rigorous counter-insurgency campaign. Though the Afghan surge did not bring the acclaim that the earlier surge to Iraq did, there were nonetheless important victories along the way, perhaps none as important as the killing of Osama bin Laden, the architect of the 9/11 attacks, in 2011. Additionally, the number of US casualties in Afghanistan peaked in the summer of 2011, and declined afterwards, especially in the months leading up to the 2012 election [@us_department_of_defense_dcas_2021-1]. At the time of the election in November of 2012, few observers could point to Afghanistan and say that the surge of forces there had not worked, but at the same time, there was little if any appetite - from politicians and the public, alike - to do anything substantially greater there. Combined with the fact that 2012 was a reelection year for the incumbent, Barack Obama, the relatively low percentage of campaign advertisements featuring the military in 2012 is, in my view, rather unsurprising. 

However, in the 2016 election, the percentage of advertisements featuring military imagery rose sharply compared to the 2012 election. The passage of time facilitated an opportunity for Americans and political candidates to think about the trajectory of US foreign and national security policy in broad and critical terms, and in particular, to evaluate US involvement in a series of messy situations and crises that had unfolded abroad, particularly in the Middle East and Eastern Europe. These included conflict in Libya and an increasingly deteriorating civil war in Syria. In particular, President Obama's handling of events in Syria in 2013, which included making but failing to enforce a now infamous "red line" policy position that alluded to US military action in the event the Assad regime used chemical weapons (which Assad did), troubled many Americans [@rhodes_inside_2018].

In many respects, Hillary Clinton, the Democratic Candidate for President in 2016, was largely seen as an extension of Barack Obama, particularly in the realm of foreign policy. Clinton had served as Obama's Secretary of State, and she was portrayed extremely negatively after a US Ambassador and three other Americans were killed on September 12, 2012, when terrorists attacked the US consulate in Benghazi, Libya [@bixby_parents_2016]. Donald Trump, an outside candidate who ran and ultimately won as a Republican, instead ran on a platform of putting "America First," which included promises to cease fighting endless wars and significantly rebuilding the US military. The combination of perceived foreign policy missteps between 20012 and 2016 and the promise of fortifying the US' strategic position likely led to the relative increase in military imagery in the 2016 presidential election.

### Specific Types of Military Imagery

Moving beyond the general incidence of military imagery across presidential elections from 2000 - 2016, Figure \@ref(fig:img-type) displays the incidence of military imagery by type in these elections. The figure shows that imagery of active duty troops and veterans are the most common forms of military imagery. It is also clear that the relative gap between active duty military imagery and veteran imagery has widened, as veteran imagery has emerged as the most common form of imagery beginning in the 2012 election.

### The Use of Military Imagery in non Defense-Themed Ads

To a large extent, we can expect that some form of military imagery would appear in advertisements that are squarely focused on issues related to defense, and that the prominence of defense issues might change, as described above, over time as particular events unfold. Yet there is another way to gauge how civilian candidates choose to leverage the military for their electoral advantages. This involves looking for instances of advertisements that are _not_ centered on defense-related issues, but which feature military imagery anyways. In such a case, the focus or theme of a particular advertisement is on an issue or a broader set of issues than those that pertain squarely to defense or national security, but by still including some type of military imagery, the candidate is, I argue, nonetheless signaling to the public that the military matters to a certain degree.

Figure \@ref(fig:non-def-theme-imagery) shows the proportion of advertisements in each election cycle that include military imagery but are _not_ squarely focused on issues pertaining to defense or veterans themes. The smoothing line in blue clearly depicts an upward trend, noting that campaign advertisements are increasingly featuring military imagery, even in those advertisements that are not directly addressing an issue related to defense or veterans issues. The data is consistent with the notion that communicating the importance of the military to the public by means of including some form of military imagery, even in ads that are not directly related to issues of defense and national security, weighs heavily in the logic of civilian political candidates and their campaign teams.

## Are Campaign Ads Increasingly Challenging Principles of Civil-Military Relations?

Having described the data in the previous section, I now pivot to answering a second, and for the purposes of the theory argued earlier in this dissertation, more substantive question, which is whether and to what degree the military images and symbols that feature in presidential campaign advertisements violate one or more of the principles of civil-military relations. 

In order to answer this important question, I must first determine which advertisements feature a military figure in a prominent way. That is, I find advertisements that include a military figure who appears in an advertisement in a noteworthy manner, or in a way that is qualitatively distinct from, for example, a passing unnamed veteran who delivers a salute on camera. I am rather interested in finding advertisements which include figures such as retired generals or admirals, veterans, or veteran family members who behave in ways that are deliberate and purposeful in terms of delivering the message of the advertisement. These types of behaviors include a military figure narrating an advertisement, or endorsing or attacking a political candidate. 

I therefore develop several additional variables which capture various military actors who appear in advertisements in prominent ways, as well as some of the potential behaviors these actors may commit. The first is a categorical variable that captures instances of various military actors _appearing_ in a prominent way in the campaign advertisement. The values this variable can take include an elite military actor (such as retired generals or admirals), a military veteran (who is not a retired general or admiral), a family member of a veteran, or a veteran _and_ members of his or her family. 

These categorical values are important because each type of military actor is likely designed to portray a slightly different type of message. Elite military actors, such as retired general and admirals, convey the rank and authority of high-ranking military officers. Civilian candidates might choose elite military actors to deliver a message in the hopes that the public will listen to them on the basis of their accrued knowledge and expertise. Non-elite veterans, on the other hand, may not be subject matter experts on specific and often complex foreign policy issues, but they might nonetheless be chosen by civilian political candidates to convey a message regarding the broader value of service to one's country. A non-elite veteran is likely in a better position, in other words, to hypothetically state in an advertisement, "I fought for my country; now I hope the country does its part by making prescription drugs more affordable" than a retired multistar general or admiral. Veteran family members, understandably, offer an even more personal and intimate connection to the public. Civilian political candidates may use veterans and/or their family members to craft emotional, heartfelt messages with the public. 

I then create variables to capture what actions, if any, these military figures who appear in a prominent way perform. I develop a series of indicator variables that correspond to behaviors that violate either the principle of non-partisanship of the military and the principle of non-interference of the military. Violation of the military's non-partisanship principle is captured by indicator variables that catalog instances of a military figure explicitly endorsing a political candidate for office, or attacking a political candidate running for office. Violation of the principle of non-interference of the military, on the other hand, is captured by an indicator variable that captures whether the military figure addresses issues that fall outside of the military figure's military expertise.  

### Prominent Appearances by Military Figures in Campaign Ads

Figure \@ref(fig:mil-endorse) shows the number of times in each election cycle that military figures appear in prominent ways during presidential campaign advertisements (in instances where the the viewer is informed that a certain candidate was "endorsed" by several former members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, whose photo is displayed during the ad, I have labeled this category as "retired generals/admirals pictured only"). 

Figure \@ref(fig:mil-endorse) portrays an interesting narrative. There were no instances of military figures appearing prominently in campaign advertisements in the 2000 Election. Then, in the 2004 election, there was an explosion of military figure prominent appearances. In 2008 and 2012, military figure prominent appearances gradually declined. Yet in 2016, the number of military figure prominent appearances increased - not quite to the levels experienced during the 2004 election, but to nonetheless relatively high levels. 

```{r mil-endorse, include=TRUE, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, error=FALSE, message=FALSE, fig.height=5, fig.width=7.5, fig.cap="Prominent Appearances of Military Figures in Presidential Campaign TV Ads, By Type of Military Actor, 2000-2016  "}

# create a df with the variables I will need
prom_figs_df <- adj_df %>% filter(vet_fam!=0) %>% select (year, count, creative, party, sponsor, ad_purpose, can_vet, can_vet_mention, vet_fam, vet_fam_end, vet_fam_atk, vet_fam_out_issues, prom_mil_fig) %>% group_by(year, party) %>% view()

# create counts of all of the pertinent variables such as 
# counts of prominent veteran appearances, prominent vet family appearances, etc.

prom_figs_df <- prom_figs_df %>%

The 2004 presidential election deserves a quick note to orient the reader to some of the underlying reasons for the high number of military figure prominent appearances (42 in total) in that election's campaign advertisements. In 2004, a number of veterans, family member of veterans, and retired officers coalesced to attack the war record of the Democratic Candidate, Senator John Kerry. The group, which was an official political action committee known as the "Swiftboat Veterans for Truth," claimed that Kerry had exaggerated his war record and was undeserving of many of the heroic medals he had received [@ullman_whats_2008]. The group even published a book that turned out to be a _New York Times_ bestseller, whose title embodied the group's main charge against Kerry: "Unfit for Command" [@buckaloo_swiftboat_nodate]. 

Although it is hard to state conclusively, the attacks levied by the Swiftboat Veterans for Truth against Kerry were almost certainly effective. One scholar argues that the combination of the veracity of the Swiftboat ads, the fact that they largely featured real veterans as opposed to paid actors, and the timing of their release (the ads were released in August, the "doldrums period between conventions," which facilitated these ads having quite a bit of exposure in the media) badly hurt Kerry's chances as a candidate [@devlin_contrasts_2005, 292].

It is not my central purpose in this chapter to render a normative judgement on the actions of the Swiftboat Veterans. One can reasonably state that such behavior was inherently partisan, for the underlying purpose of the group was to prevent Kerry from ascending to the Presidency. From this perspective, the actions of the Swiftboat Veterans must be viewed as wrong in that they violated the military's non-partisan ethic. On the other hand, one might also conclude that the attacks came primarily from Kerry's fellow Vietnam Veterans and for the central purpose of, at least from the Swiftboat Veterans perspective, correcting Kerry's untruthful and embellished war record. Considering the divisions in American society that the Vietnam War revealed, one might reasonably conclude that while the impact of the Swiftboat Veterans actions was partisan, their main intent (though certainly not that of the Republican Party) was to set the record straight on Kerry rather than to meddle in partisan politics. 

Regardless of one's normative opinion on the actions of the Swiftboat Veterans for Truth in 2004, there is a much more significant story that needs to be explained given the data presented in Figure \@ref(fig:mil-endorse), in my view. This significant story involves the fact that there are still a relatively large number of military figure prominent appearances in elections besides 2004, when the candidates running for office were not veterans (2012 and 2016).

Moreover, Figure \@ref(fig:actor-principle) reveals several interesting points. First, Panel A shows that across all types of military figures who appear prominently in a campaign ad, these figures engage in overtly partisan behaviors when they do appear, such as attacking or endorsing candidates. The 2004 election elicited the greatest number of prominent military figure appearances (42 in total), which included 21 attacks, 11 endorsements, and 1 instance of addressing a topic that was tangential to military expertise. In 2016, on the other hand, out of 32 total military figure prominent appearances, there were 25 attacks, 15 endorsements, and three instances of addressing a topic that was tangential to military expertise. To the degree that it _may_ have been possible for a military figure to prominently appear in a campaign ad and not engage in an overtly partisan behavior - a claim that is questionable to begin with - the data indicate that, rather unsurprisingly, when military figures appear, they routinely and increasingly engage in explicitly partisan acts. 

This trend seems to hold across all types of military figures. For instance, Panel B indicates that of the two retired general/admiral appearances in the 2000 election, one involved addressing a topic outside of military expertise, but none explicitly endorses or attacked a political candidate. In 2008, the number of retired general/admiral appearances equaled the number of endorsements. And in 2016, of the ten retired generals or admirals who appeared prominently in campaign ads, these appearances included seven attacks and five endorsements. 

### On which Party's Behalf are Military Figures Violating the Principles of Civil-Military Relations? 

Given that civilian actors are increasingly airing campaign ads that feature military actors committing explicitly partisan behaviors, it is important to discern whether such behavior is serving the interests of one political party over another. One might suspect, given a moderate amount of literature that the US military more closely associates with the Republican Party than the Democratic Party [@davis_attitudes_2001; @ricks_widening_1997; see also @golby_duty_2011], that military figures engage in more partisan activity on behalf of the Republican rather than the Democratic Party. However, the results indicate otherwise. 

Figure \@ref(fig:behavior-party) displays the total number of military figure prominent appearances, endorsements, attacks, and instances of addressing issues that are tangential to military expertise separated by the party supported by the advertisement. The results indicate that from 2000-2016, with the exception of the 2012 election, military figures who appear prominently during campaign ads engage in partisan behaviors more often on behalf of Democratic rather than Republican candidates.

Panels A and C of Figure \@ref(fig:behavior-party) show that the _only_ times that Democratic-affiliated military figure partisan activity during campaign ads did not outpace that of Republican-affiliated military figure appearances occurred in 2012, when the number of military figure appearances on behalf of Republican candidates were slightly higher (Panel A), and when military figures attacked political candidates more than Democratic-affiliated military figures (Panel C). 

Are these results inconsistent with literature suggesting that the military is more closely aligned with the Republican than the Democratic Party? I suggest that in answering this important question, it is important to remember the distinction between _non-visible ideological alignment_ and _visible partisan behavior_. The traditional view that the military is ideologically affiliated with the Republican Party more than the Democratic Party relies on a thorough body of survey data in which researchers compared the attitudes of military officers in the late 1990s to a diverse set of civilian groups [@feaver_soldiers_2001].^[These surveys were spearheaded by the Triangle Institute for Security Studies (TISS), a joint effort between researchers at Duke University and the University of North Carolina at Chapel-Hill.]. This survey data itself constitutes an impressive body of scholarship aimed at determining whether and the degree to which a gap existed between the military and civilians, and what form such a gap took [@feaver_soldiers_2001; see also @ricks_widening_1997; @golby_duty_2011; and @golby_thanks_2016]. 

The TISS survey data - more than 20 years old - showed that the military overwhelmingly identified with the Republican Party, to the point that among military leaders, 63.9% identified with Republicans, compared to 8.1% with Democrats, 16.7% with Independents, and 11.3% with no or another political party [@holsti_chasms_2001, 28]. When asked to identify their own ideological affiliation in liberal or conservative terms, similar results emerged among military leaders: only 4.4% identified as "very liberal" or "somewhat liberal," compared to 37.5% of civilian non-veteran leaders and 28.5% of the public who were not veterans [@holsti_chasms_2001, 33]. Some scholars of civil-military relations saw the ideological gap reflected in these results as concerning in that the ideological beliefs of the military officer corps varied too much from those of the American public. 

However, there is a significant difference between invisible ideological preferences held by military officers and visible partisan behaviors committed by them. The latter _proves_ that the military is failing to uphold to a principle of non-partisanship. The former, on the other hand, may still a cause for concern, but only insofar as an ideological imbalance may lead to _behavior_ that favors one party over another. 

A lot has changed in the more than two decades since the TISS survey data was collected. It is possible, and perhaps likely, that the military no longer shares as strong as an ideological connection to the Republican Party as it did in the late 1980s and 1990s. More recent data is necessary in order to draw such a conclusion. 

It could also be that the trends uncovered in this chapter of military figures engaging in explicitly partisan behavior more frequently on behalf of Democratic candidates than Republican candidates indicate that Democratic candidates want to convey to the public that they are not weaker than or inferior to Republican candidates on defense-related issues. Democratic candidates may desire to employ a military figure to endorse them, or to attack their political opponent, because doing so might make the Democratic candidate appear strong. Such a possibility is consistent with the "issue ownership" literature in American politics, which suggests that the political parties are known to have advantages in certain issue areas [@petrocik_issue_2003; @sides_consequences_2007]. Such a possibility poses the basis for fertile research in the future, especially as polarized politics in the US endure and as several recent events - to include the withdrawal of the military from Afghanistan, and very contentious Congressional testimony by military leaders in its aftermath - may signal that any actual or perceived ties between the military and the GOP are weakening. 

## Explaining Campaign Ads that Feature Explicitly Partisan Behavior by Military Figures

The next several paragraphs reveal the results of regression analysis for a series of different model specifications. I control for military prestige by including a measure of public trust and confidence in the military, as reported through Gallup public opinion polling regarding trust in institutions [@noauthor_confidence_2020]. This control variable is intended to capture the intuition that civilians are more likely to use the military for their own partisan gain and purposes as military prestige rises. 

Consistent with the regression analysis conducted in the previous chapter, I include several measurements of polarization. These include separate measurements of ideology in the US House and Senate [@jeffrey_b_lewis_voteview_2020], and a measure of affective polarization, which measures how partisans who identify with one political party generally feel about the other political party as reported in data from the American National Election Studies (ANES) [@iyengar_affect_2012; @iyengar_strengthening_2018; @iyengar_origins_2019]. 

In some model specifications, I include several other control variables that could theoretically drive variation in the level and frequency of explicitly partisan behavior conducted by military figures in civilian campaign advertisements. These include a measure of military casualties sustained in a given year, and whether at least one candidate mentioned in the advertisement is a veteran.^[This variable is constructed from a number of sources, and consists of the number of hostile US casualties sustained in a given calendar year per 100,000 Active Duty military forces. I include in this measurement those casualties that are the result of what the Department of Defense classifies as either "hostile action" or a "terrorist attack." Annual data is provided from the Department of Defense from 1980-2010.  I then used data from the Department of Defense regarding the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan to construct a measurement for years outside of this time range. See @department_of_defense_dcas_2011; @department_of_defense_dcas_2021; @department_of_defense_dcas_2021-1; @department_of_defense_dcas_2021-2; @department_of_defense_dcas_2021-3; @department_of_defense_dcas_2021-4; @department_of_defense_dcas_2021-5; @department_of_defense_dmdc_2021 for more details.] I control for the level of military casualties sustained through hostile action in a given year because troop casualty levels may make civilian candidates more willing to use military figures to attack and/or endorse political candidates, especially if the views of these candidates on the use of force strongly align or clash with those held by a particular type of military figure. I include a candidate's veteran status because civilian candidates who themselves are veterans may likewise spur their political opponents to employ military figures in ways that undermine the veteran candidates service record or views regarding the use of force. 

The dependent variables in each model is a dichotomous indicator of the log odds of a military figure appearing prominently in a campaign advertisement (Models 1-3) and explicitly endorsing a candidate, attacking a candidate, or addressing a topic that falls outside of the military figure's expertise (Models 4-8). Models 1-6 are logistic regressions, and models 7-8 are mixed models that includes year random effects to allow for the possibility that a particular election cycle in a given year has special characteristics that are driving variation in the dependent variable. The results of these regressions are displayed in Table \@ref(tab:regression6) on the following page.

### Regression Analysis

```{r reg data manipulation, include=FALSE, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, error=FALSE}

# prep the data 
reg_df <- adj_df %>% select (year, count, creative, party, sponsor, ad_purpose, can_vet, can_vet_mention, vet_fam, vet_fam_end, vet_fam_atk, vet_fam_out_issues, prom_mil_fig, def_vet_ad_theme:sum_non_def_vet_ad_theme) %>% group_by(year, party) %>% view() 


# create explicit variables for each partisan action of endorse, attack, speak out on tangential issues.  
# vet_fam_end ==1 or if vet_fam_atk ==1 or if vet_fam_out_issues ==1

# also, use include several control variables to the data frame.  
reg_df <- reg_df %>% mutate(
  partisan_act=case_when(vet_fam_end ==1 | vet_fam_atk ==1 | vet_fam_out_issues ==1 ~ 1, (vet_fam_end !=1 & vet_fam_atk!=1 & vet_fam_out_issues!=1)~0),
```

The regression results provide general support for H3, which stated that civilian actors increasingly leverage the military for their own political purposes and advantages when military prestige is high relative to periods of low military prestige. Across all model specifications, trust in the military is positive and statistically significant, suggesting that civilians employ the military and military figures differently when prestige is relatively higher. In other words, the statistical evidence supports the notion that increasing military prestige indeed provides an _opportunity_ for civilian actors to involve the military in politics. 

In models 1-3, where the dependent variable is the log odds of a military figure appearing prominently in a campaign advertisement, and only controls are the levels of trust in the military and political polarization, the coefficient on polarization is negative, which interestingly suggests that increasing polarization decreases the likelihood that a civilian candidate will employ the military to appear in a prominent way, or to commit an explicitly partisan act, such as endorsing or attacking a candidate during the campaign advertisement. This is a potentially interesting finding, as it suggests that rising polarization could offset increasing military prestige. Statistically speaking, however, across all model specifications, the coefficient on various measures of polarization are not consistently significant. The coefficient for polarization is even positive in model 8. Therefore, I do not strongly suspect that polarization has consistent explanatory power in terms of impacting how civilian candidates employ the military in campaign ads, given the results of these regressions. 

In models 4-8, where the dependent variable is the log odds of a military figure either endorsing or attacking a candidate, or addressing a topic that is outside of military expertise, military prestige continues to remain statistically significant and positive, even as we introduce other control variables. However, as models 5-6 show, when we include controls for the hostile casualty rate and whether at least one of the candidates mentioned in an advertisement is a veteran, these other control variables also are statistically significant. The negative coefficients on hostile casualty rate in models 5-6 suggest that rising casualty levels decrease the likelihood that a military figure commits an explicitly partisan act while appearing in a campaign advertisement, and the positive coefficient on a candidate's veteran status suggests that military figures are in fact more likely to endorse or attack candidates who themselves served in the military. These findings are interesting in themselves, and further research could investigate these claims. 

Substantively, the coefficient for trust in the military of .381 (model 6) indicates that a one unit increase in percentage of the public that places a high degree or quite a lot of confidence in the military results in a 46.4 percent increase in the odds that a military figure endorses or attacks a political candidate, or addresses a topic that is outside of military expertise, while appearing in a campaign advertisement. 

Furthermore, the statistically significant and negative coefficient for Party-GOP (models 4-8) suggests that advertisements aired in support of GOP candidates are less likely to feature military figures committing explicitly partisan acts of behavior relative to the baseline group, which are ads aired in support of the Democratic party.^[The coefficient for Party-Other captures ads that are aired in support of candidates who represent parties other than the Republicans or Democrats, such as the Libertarian or Green parties.] However, I suspect that the high number of military figure endorsements and attacks that occurred in campaign ads during the 2004 election, when John Kerry ran against George W. Bush, are largely responsible for these results. The key statistical finding for the purposes of the theory offered in this dissertation, and the hypotheses offered in this chapter, is that even when these additional controls of party, hostile casualty rate, and candidate veteran status are included, the coefficient for trust in the military remains positive and significant. 

Finally, the coefficient for trust in the military remains positive in models 7 -8, which are mixed models that control only for trust in the military and polarization, but include year random effects to allow for the possibility that particular, unobserved characteristics impact a particular election differently. In both of these specifications, the coefficient for trust in the military remains positive and statistically significant. These findings reinforce the general intuition that the level of military prestige plays an important role in whether and how civilian candidates employ military figures in campaign ads, and in particular, the degree to which they wish these figures who do appear to engage in explicitly partisan behaviors.

## Predicted Probability

In order to further demonstrate the substantive impact of military prestige on the likelihood that military figures engage in acts of behavior that violate the principle of non-partisanship or non-interference, I transform the regression results from Table \@ref(tab:regression6) into predicted probabilities. Figure \@ref(fig:pred-prob-ch4-mod1-aff) plots the predicted probability of military figures either endorsing or attacking a political candidate, or addressing topics that are tangential to military expertise, while appearing in a presidential campaign advertisement. Using the results of the logistic regression in Model 6, I fix the level of affective polarization and the hostile troop casualty rate at their respective means. I hold the value of candidate-veteran at 0, denoting that the candidates portrayed in a hypothetical ad are not veterans, and hold the value of the party that the advertisement supports as the Republican Party. The vertical colored lines indicate the level of military prestige as measured by public opinion polling in certain points of time in US history [@noauthor_confidence_2020]. The color of the line indicates the party of the President who was in office at the time.
