The vertical axis of the graph remains at or near zero for values of military prestige that are somewhat moderate, but at higher levels of military prestige, the vertical axis climbs steadily. When the level of military prestige is at 85, as was the case at the completion of the Gulf War against Iraq in February 1991, there is a greater than 50% predicted probability that a campaign advertisement ran by a civilian candidate features a military figure engaging in a partisan act during the advertisement. High levels of military prestige also existed in 2003, presumably as a result of the invasion of Iraq that began in the same year. 

The data examined in this study, which ran from 2000 - 2016, unfortunately do not allow for a richer comparison of the military's inclusion in presidential campaign ads over time. It would be extremely valuable, in my view, to be able to extend the analysis further back in time, in order to see whether at values of lower military prestige than were examined in this chapter - such as those which existed in the late 1970s and early 1980s - the trends uncovered in this chapter still hold. Similarly, this chapter did not include data from the 2020 election - an election that was contentious to say the least. Future work can, and should, extend the analysis completed in this chapter, as doing so might refine the role that military prestige plays in the calculus of civilians when determining what content to display during campaign advertisements. 

## Alternate Explanations

Before concluding the statistical analysis, it is worth thinking about potential alternate explanations that could also be responsible for driving the increase in partisan actions committed by military figures who appear prominently in campaign advertisements. What else, besides the level of military prestige, might be responsible for the patterns and trends uncovered in this chapter?

In my view, the most compelling alternate explanation is not necessarily an altogether alternate explanation, but rather a more precise definition or measurement of the components that shape military prestige. In developing the theory offered in this dissertation in chapter two, I noted that military prestige is a comprehensive and multi-faceted concept. Specifically, I argued in chapter two that the level of military prestige is shaped by several components, including institutional features of the military, which impact its relative influence within and across the whole of government, as well as societal features, to include the degree that the military is esteemed by the public. These components of military prestige are likely further comprised of other components or building blocks. For example, the degree to which the military is esteemed by the public likely rests on several factors, including the degree of felt separation between those who serve and those who do not (one of "the gaps" between the military and the public), and the perceived performance of the military in recent events, such as wars [@feaver_soldiers_2001;@schake_warriors_2016]. We can, and this dissertation has, measured the combined effects of all of these component factors of military prestige by relying on measures of public trust in the military [@noauthor_confidence_2020].

The point in revisiting the notion of military prestige being shaped by multiple subcomponents is to argue that it is _possible_ that one or more of these subcomponents - institutional influence, societal esteem, and/or performance in recent wars or conflicts - is more responsible for shaping variation in the dependent variables examined in this chapter more than the other subcomponents. However, it is difficult, if not impossible, to measure many of these subcomponents of military prestige, or at least to do so reliably. For example, did the United States lose in Iraq and in Afghanistan? The answer to this question is not crystal clear, and even if it were, the perceived answer to this question might very well have been different if we had asked the same question at the height of these conflicts, say in 2004 or in 2008.^[Future scholarship, with the benefit of hindsight and the passage of time, may render more definitively whether such wars ought to be coded dichotomously, but applying such a measurement scheme to these wars, in this chapter, would be irresponsible, in my view.] 

Although measuring the individual subcomponents of military prestige is difficult, it is nonetheless possible to at least trace the _logic_ for why one type of subcomponent might be more responsible for shaping the level of military prestige than other subcomponents, at least over the time period examined in this chapter. As Figure \@ref(fig:pred-prob-ch4-mod1-aff) shows, for example, the highest measurements of military prestige occurred right at time periods when the military had either won a war (February 1991) or was initiating a major war (2003). At the very least, Iraq had not yet become rife with sectarian violence, nor had the American public began to weary of the US' involvement there. Figure \@ref(fig:pred-prob-ch4-mod1-aff) also shows, importantly, that the lowest moments of military prestige occurred in the 1970s and early 1980s, which coincide with the era after Vietnam. The end of the Vietnam War, and the immediate years which followed, were difficult years for the military. Rife with indiscipline, the military and those who served in it returned from Vietnam not respected or revered by the American public, but ostracized. One military historian, Roger Spiller, has noted that the United States Army in particular was an "institutional wreck" at the end of the Vietnam War [@spiller_shadow_1997, 42]. It is no wonder, then, that the US military's prestige was indeed lowest at the end of the Vietnam War and in the years to follow. 

Under such logic, one might conclude that it is the military's performance in war that shapes not only the level of military prestige that arises, but importantly, also the civilian choice to leverage the military in politics, including how and the degree to which the military appears in campaign advertisements. My view, however, is that while such a view is entirely possible, it is nonetheless incomplete, for the reason that the other subcomponents of military prestige - the military's relative institutional influence and its relationship with society - are also varying at the same time, and at least partly as a result of the military's performance in war. For example, the military's relationship with society is always evolving, and the Vietnam War was fought under a compulsory (draft) system of military service. The Gulf War, on the other hand, involved an all-volunteer force, as have all conflicts since the mid-1970s. Additionally, the military's institutional influence within the government has certainly changed over time, especially as institutional reforms such as the Goldwater-Nichols Act have taken root within the military, and as the military's role in conflicts such as Iraq and Afghanistan vis-a-vis other institutions, such as the State Department, have varied. Simply put, the relationship and correlation between the military's performance in war, its relative institutional influence within government, and the military's relationship with society make a definitive judgment very difficult regarding which of these factors is most responsible for driving the level of military prestige. So we cannot rule out the possibility that one or more subcomponents of military prestige are more responsible than others in shaping military prestige and the civilian choice to feature the military in campaign ads, but neither can we definitively state that this is the case. 

It is also important to briefly comment on whether norm change is a potential alternate explanation from the perspective of civilian actors. In other words, is it possible that civilian candidates and their campaign teams have simply increasingly adopted the behavior of using the military - images, symbols, and military figures - in campaign ads? Have civilian actors simply come to see the behavior of using the military in campaign ads - and in ways that violate the central principles of civil-military relations - as less "taboo" than it used to be [@tannenwald_nuclear_1999]? 

In my view, norm change might be _somewhat_ responsible for the variation uncovered in this chapter, but nonetheless _not the primary_ reason for the variation. In other words, to the degree that norm change may play a role in shaping the decision by civilians to feature the military in campaign ads, its role, if any, should be considered small and less compelling than changes in the level of military prestige. There are two main reasons to suspect that this is a balanced and accurate view of the trends uncovered in this chapter.

First, it is true that while civilian actors are expected to adhere to the principles of civil-military relations, they do not constitute a professional body in the way that the military does, and thus, civilian actors may not be expected to adhere as strongly to the principles of non-partisanship and non-interference of the military as the military is. Thus, it is entirely possible that civilian candidates might learn from the perceived success of civilian candidates using the military in prominent ways during campaign advertisements in previous elections, and then use the military in similar ways themselves.

Second, however, the empirical record uncovered in this chapter does not reflect a story of civilian political candidates gradually learning from and implementing such behavior. For instance, Table \@ref(tab:desc-stats) in the beginning of this chapter showed that the percentage of ads in each election cycle that contain military imagery does not vary linearly over time. The same trends were also revealed in the majority of graphs featured in this chapter. If norm change is in fact the most compelling explanation of the variation in the use of the military in campaign ads by civilian actors, we would more than likely see more linear patterns of the military appearing or behaving in particular ways during campaign advertisements over time. The empirical patterns we see, however, do not seem to support such an explanation. Thus, while civilian political candidates can and likely do learn lessons from what works and does not work with respect to campaign advertising in elections, the record does not support norm change as the most compelling and underlying reason for driving patterns of civilian incorporation of the military into campaign advertising during presidential elections. 

# An Assessment of the 'Motives and Opportunities' Framework in the US Case

This section of the chapter pauses to offer an initial assessment of the motives and opportunities framework offered in chapter two of this dissertation. It is appropriate to conduct such an assessment now, having completed two major empirical analyses, each of a political behavior conducted primarily by one type of actor engaged in the conduct of civil=military relations. The previous chapter examined opinion commentary authored by military figures and published in major newspapers, and this chapter examined the incorporation of the military by civilian political candidates and their campaign teams into presidential campaign advertisements. In this section, I will briefly review what we now know, highlight what we do not yet know, and outline the way forward for the remainder of the dissertation. 

## What We Know 

In chapter two of this dissertation, I outlined four hypotheses, which are listed below for reference. 

H1: Military actors are increasingly active in a partisan manner when polarization is high relative to periods of low polarization.

H2: The overall level of political behaviors committed by military actors that challenge the fundamental principles of civil-military relations is higher in environments marked by high polarization and high military prestige relative to other types of environments. 

H3: Civilian actors increasingly leverage the military for their own political purposes and advantages when military prestige is high relative to periods of low military prestige. 

H4: The overall level of political behaviors committed by civilian actors that challenge the fundamental principles of civil-military relations is higher in environments marked by high polarization and high military prestige relative to other types of environments. 

At this point in the dissertation, I have found strong support for H1 and H3, and mixed support for H2 and H4. Strong support for H1 was found in chapter three of this dissertation, which concluded that rising political polarization is the most consistent and statistically significant explanation for the likelihood that published retired military officer commentary violates either the principle of civilian control, non-partisanship, or non-interference. Even after controlling for other variables, to include the author's rank achieved during their time on active duty, the hostile casualty rate sustained by military forces in a given year, and whether an opinion piece was authored during an election year, the coefficients for political polarization across a variety of model specifications were positive and statistically significant, lending strong support for the notion that in the US framework of civil-military relations, political polarization, especially when conceptualized as the clash of worldviews that shape and influence the fundamental values that influence, shape, and govern society, serve as a _motive_ for the military to intervene in politics.

Strong support for H3 was found in this fourth chapter of the dissertation, which, after examining the content of presidential campaign advertising, a behavior that is primarily conducted by civilian actors, concluded that rising military prestige is positively and statistically significantly associated with not only greater frequency of military imagery appearing in campaign advertisements, but greater likelihood that campaign advertisements will include military figures who commit behaviors that violate the principle of non-partisanship and/or non-interference of the military. This finding itself contributes to the scholarly understanding of how various actors are increasingly willing to overlook normative standards out of a desire to see his or her preferred candidate win office [see also @graham_democracy_2020]. 

The empirical record uncovered in this chapter also showed that military figures tend to endorse or attack political candidates, or speak out on issues that are tangential to their own military expertise, on behalf of Democratic presidential candidates moreso than on behalf of Republican candidates. This result is consistent with the "issue ownership" literature, and in particular the notion that suggests the Republican party is generally considered more skilled in matters of defense and national security and thus, more closely tied to the military, than the Democratic Party [@petrocik_issue_2003; @sides_consequences_2007]. However, this result also provides a richer contextual understanding of previous scholarly literature that found that members of the military more closely associate with the Republican party than the Democratic party [@ricks_widening_1997; @davis_attitudes_2001; @holsti_chasms_2001; see also @golby_duty_2011]. It could be that this past literature, which is 10-25 years old, is no longer valid in that service members' attitudes no longer more closely associate with the Republican party than with the Democratic party. Regardless, there is an important distinction between political attitudes and performed political behaviors, and this chapter clearly demonstrated that with respect to one form of the latter, more are occurring on behalf of the Democratic party than on behalf of the Republicans. Even after controlling for other variables, to include whether a candidate is a veteran, and the hostile casualty rate sustained by military forces in a given year, the level of military prestige proves to be a positive and statistically significant factor associated with how military images appear and the behavior of military figures in presidential campaign ads. These results provide strong support for the notion that military prestige indeed provides an _opportunity_ for civilian actors to involve the military in politics. 

Therefore, we now know that at a minimum, each actor type involved in the conduct of civil-military relations in the US seems to respond differently to changing levels of military prestige (civilians) and political polarization (military actors). When integrated, it seems, then, that there is general support for the notion of a "motives and opportunities" framework that exists in the contemporary United States for the military's involvement in politics, at least with respect to two very specific political behaviors. Such a result is in line with previous scholarly works that have used a motives and opportunities framework in general and other comparative contexts [@finer_man_1962; @taylor_politics_2003]. 

## What We Do Not Yet Know

However, there is still much that is unclear regarding the relationship between political polarization, military prestige, and the political behaviors that challenge the central principles of civil-military relations. There are at least two items of interest that remain unknown at the moment, each of which I address in turn. 

The first involves an issue of external validity with respect to the types of political behaviors each actor type can make. The trends uncovered in chapters three and four thus far each involve only one type of political behavior, and it is not clear the extent to which, if at all, the same trends apply to other types of political behaviors that each actor type can commit. While a statistical analysis of every type of political behavior that civilian and military actors can commit is not possible in this dissertation, H2 and H4 both nonetheless make predictions about the _overall level_ of political behaviors that each actor type commits when the relative levels of political polarization and military prestige are combined, and when one of the four types of domestic environments, as shown in Table \@ref(tab:poss-environment-ch4), exists. 

Each hypothesis in particular posits that each actor type will engage in more political behaviors that violate the central principles of civil-military relations when both polarization and military prestige exist at relatively high levels. As of now, the data uncovered in chapters 3 and 4 do not facilitate making such a pronouncement. Each chapter involved focusing on an important, but nonetheless only one, type of political behavior. The analysis completed thus far does not allow the researcher to claim that multiple types of political behaviors might react the same way as a result of changes in the level of political polarization and military prestige.  

A second item of interest that remains unknown at this time involves how military actors in particular respond to levels of military prestige. The main thrust of this dissertation, and this chapter in particular, examines how civilian actors respond to rising military prestige. And indeed, the notion that rising military prestige provides an _opportunity_ for civilians to involve the military in politics, rather than an _opportunity_ for the military to involve itself in politics, is the primary claim made in this dissertation. 

Still, it would be helpful if the relationship between rising military prestige and military actors could be clarified. In chapter two of this dissertation, I argued that it was not clear if military actors uniformly respond to rising military prestige the same way, as theoretically, at least two responses might be possible. The first was that military actors might respond to higher levels of military prestige by being emboldened to behave in ways that challenge or violate the principles of civil-military relations. The basis for this expectation stems from the fact that these military actors know that they are popular and respected by the public, and that they might believe that because this is true, they can, on occasion, flaunt the principles to which they otherwise must adhere to. The second possible response, however, was that military actors who know they are prestigious do not want to lose the potential public influence that they have, and therefore would not act or behave in such a way so as to jeopardize the strong rapport that they have a public. One response to higher military prestige expects a bolder military that selectively violates the principles of civil-military relations, while one predicts a military that more tightly adheres to them. Further clarifying the direction of this possible relationship, even if a uniform expectation is not possible, would solidify that the relationship between civilian actors and military prestige truly indeed is the right relationship to emphasize. 

## The Way Forward

This dissertation now pivots to explore historical case studies, which will help better inform the impact of polarization and military prestige on the overall level of political behaviors committed by civilian and military actors, and clarify the relationship between rising military prestige and the political behaviors committed by military actors in particular. The first case study, undertaken in the next chapter, explores political behaviors committed by civilian and military actors involving the military in the period from immediately after the US Civil War through the middle of the Gilded Age. This historical era runs approximately from 1865 - 1885, and involves the evolution of an era marked by high political polarization and high military prestige to one characterized by high polarization and low military prestige. 

The second case study, undertaken immediately after the first, examines the political behaviors committed by civilian and military actors from the end of the Vietnam War to the period immediately after the Gulf War. This historical era runs from approximately 1973 - 1992, and spans a period in which political polarization and military prestige evolved from levels in which both were relatively low, to one in which political polarization was still low, but military prestige was high. 

In each of these case studies, military prestige varies, while the level of polarization remains constant within each. This is a deliberate decision, largely stemming from the fact that the empirical analysis thus far completed has involved somewhat greater variation in the level of polarization than in the level of military prestige. However, each of the case studies involves a different relative level of polarization. Thus, together, the case studies will enable a meaningful comparison, both within and across cases, to better understand how polarization and military prestige impact the political behaviors committed by civilian and military actors.

# Appendix to Chapter Four

\doublespace

This chapter Appendix roughly aligns with the chronological order of the chapter.   

## Note on the Campaign Media Analysis Group and its Role in the Data

WiscAD and WMP gather the television advertisements with the assistance of a commercial company, the Campaign Media Analysis Group (CMAG). CMAG provides several pieces of information when releasing the data, such as the media market in which a particular advertisement aired, the estimated cost of running a particular advertisement, the time of day the advertisement was run, and other variables. A group of scholars and graduate students affiliated with WiscAD and WMP then conduct additional coding on the advertisements. This coding varies to some extent by election cycle, but otherwise remains markedly similar. The additional variables that are coded for in each election cycle include items such as the specific issues that an advertisement mentions or addresses during the advertisement, whether a candidate is featured during the advertisement, and whether a given advertisement takes on a negative tone, and more. 

Cleaning the data from five separate data sets was a considerable project. I had to merge several variables and implement a common naming scheme across the data in order to enable a meaningful comparison of the data over time. The .rmd file that contains the cleaning instructions is available for review. 

## Robustness and Endogeneity Tests

In this section of the Appendix, I conduct a series of robustness checks and tests for endogeneity using regression analysis. I present the results and briefly discuss the results and implications of each in turn. 

### Robustness Tests

The dependent variable used in the chapter's main regression table was the likelihood that a military figure appeared in an campaign advertisement and violated any of the central principles of civil-military relations by conducting one of three specific types of behaviors: endorsing a candidate for office, attacking a candidate running for office, or addressing an outside issue. the first two behaviors are different manifestations of violating the principle of non-partisanship, while the third is a manifestation of violating the principle of non-interference of the military. 

In the regression table to follow, I make each of these three behaviors a separate dependent variable in order to test the finding that the level of military prestige drives how civilians implement military figures in campaign ads, and specifically, whether we can be precise to predict that changes in the level of military prestige are robust to particular types of behaviors, rather than a conglomerate of the three behaviors, as used in the main regression table. I also include several OLS models where the dependent variable is the proportion of ads in each election cycle that contains military imagery altogether, of any type. 

The results of these regressions are displayed in Table \@ref(tab:regression7).

\singlespace

```{r Regression Robustness Tests_ch4, include=TRUE, echo=FALSE, results="asis", warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
stargazer(mod2_house, mod2_senate, mod3_senate, mod3_aff, mod4_house, mod4_aff, mod5_mil_img_cycle_house, mod5_mil_img_cycle_sen, mod5_mil_img_cycle_aff,
          type="latex",
          label="tab:regression7",
          title="Robustness Checks (Violations of Each Principle Separately and Proportion of Ads Featuring Military Imagery in Each Election Cycle)", 
          covariate.labels = c('Trust in Military', 'House Polarization', 'Senate Polarization', 'Aff. Polarization', 'Hostile Casualty Rate', 'Candidate-Veteran'),
          dep.var.labels = c('Endorse', 'Attack', 'Address Outside Issue', 'Proportion of Ads with Military Imagery'),
          model.names=TRUE,
          header=FALSE,
          column.sep.width = "1pt",
          align=TRUE,
          font.size="small",
          no.space=TRUE,
          omit.stat=c("f", "ser"),
          float.env="sidewaystable"
          
          )
```
\doublespace

There are several important takeaways from Table \@ref(tab:regression7). The first is that the finding from the main regression table regarding military prestige is robust to two of the three behavioral specifications for violating the central principles of civil-military relations. Indeed, as models 1-4 show, changes in the level of trust in the military are positive and statistically significant when the dependent variable is instances of endorsing a political candidate (models 1-2) as well as instances of attacking a political candidate (models 3-4). However, the results are not robust to a specification of the dependent variable as addressing issues that are tangential to military expertise, as shown in models 5-6 of Table \@ref(tab:regression7). Thus, the results predict that as the military becomes increasingly trusted by the public, civilian political candidates are more likely to use military figures in campaign ads to make endorsements of political candidates, and to render attacks against political opponents, but we cannot state that rising levels of military trust will also definitively result in increasing instances of military figures addressing topics that fall outside of military expertise. 

### Checking for Endogeneity

In this section of the Appendix, I again check for endogeneity, and in particular, the relationship between military prestige and instances of military figures appearing in civilian campaign advertisements who either endorse or attack political candidates, or address a topic that is tangential to or outside of military expertise. Table \@ref(tab:regression7) presents the result of several OLS regression models in which the dependent variable is military prestige, as measured by the level of public trust and confidence in the military. I again include several control variables, including different measures of polarization, as well as an interaction term between the level of polarization and instances in which military figures appear in campaign ads and violate one or more of the central standards of civil-military relations. 

\singlespace
```{r endogeneity checks_ch4, include=TRUE, echo=FALSE, results="asis", warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

stargazer(mod10_ch4_endog_house, mod10_ch4_endog_sen, mod10_ch4_endog_house_int_simple, mod10_ch4_endog_sen_int_simple, mod10_ch4_endog_house_int, mod10_ch4_endog_sen_int,
          type="latex",
          label="tab:regression7",
          title="Regression Results: Endogeneity Checks (Regress Military Prestige on Polarization and an Instance of a Military Figure Violating a Central Principle during a Campaign Ad)", 
          covariate.labels = c('Violation', 'House Polarization', 'Senate Polarization', 'Hostile Casualty Rate', 'Candidate-Veteran', 'Violation*House Polarization', 'Violation*Senate Polarization'),
          dep.var.labels = c('Military Prestige'),
          model.names=TRUE,
          header=FALSE,
          column.sep.width = "1pt",
          align=TRUE,
          font.size="small",
          no.space=TRUE,
          omit.stat=c("f", "ser")
          )
```
\doublespace

The main concern again in checking for endogeneity deals with the directionality of the system of variables involved. In the particular setting of this chapter, then, we are attempting to determine whether there is strong evidence that instances of a military figure violating a central principle drives the level of military prestige, as opposed to what I have claimed - that military prestige drives the civilian choice or willingness of civilian candidates to use military figures who behave in ways that violate or challenge the principles of civil-military relations. 

The results of the regressions in Table \@ref(tab:regression7) suggest that there is low-moderate endogeneity in the data, but ultimately, not to a level that calls into question the results obtained in the main regression table in this chapter. From left to right, models 1-6 first involve no interaction term between polarization and an instance of a military figure violating one of the principles of civil-military relations (models 1-2), then include models in which an interaction term is included, but controls for the hostile casualty rate and whether are a candidate is a veteran are removed (models 3-4), and then finally include models in which these controls are re-instated along with appropriate interaction terms (models 5-6). 

The coefficient on violation is positive and highly statistically significant in models 1-4, which could prove problematic by itself, but when we reinstate other control variables in models 5-6, the statistical significance for the coefficient on violation falls away. In addition, in models 5-6, the coefficient for the interaction term between violation*polarization (house and senate, respectively) is statistically insignificant and slightly negative. 

I run a series of additional checks that include a dummy variable for the 2004 Election, as that was an election held at a time at which the military was highly prestigious, and when casualties were relatively high, when several of the candidates were veterans (to include George W. Bush and John Kerry, the main candidates), and an election in which the Swiftboat Veterans and other military figures appeared rather frequently and engaged in frequent partisan behaviors. I am interested in determining whether the coefficient for the dummy on 2004, in other words, picks up a lot of the magnitude and statistical significance that was present on the coefficient for violation in the previous regression table. 

The results are displayed in Table \@ref(tab:regression8). 

\singlespace
```{r endogeneity checks_ch4_part2, include=TRUE, echo=FALSE, results="asis", warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

stargazer(mod10_ch4_endog_house_dummy, mod10_ch4_endog_sen_dummy, mod10_ch4_endog_house_int_simple_dummy, mod10_ch4_endog_sen_int_simple_dummy, mod10_ch4_endog_house_int_dummy, mod10_ch4_endog_sen_int_dummy,
          type="latex",
          label="tab:regression8",
          title="Regression Results: Endogeneity Checks with a 2004 dummy (Regress Military Prestige on Polarization and an Instance of a Military Figure Violating a Central Principle during a Campaign Ad)", 
          covariate.labels = c('Violation', 'House Polarization', 'Senate Polarization', 'Hostile Casualty Rate', 'Candidate-Veteran', '2004 Election', 'Violation*House Polarization', 'Violation*Senate Polarization'),
          dep.var.labels = c('Military Prestige'),
          model.names=TRUE,
          header=FALSE,
          column.sep.width = "1pt",
          align=TRUE,
          font.size="small",
          no.space=TRUE,
          omit.stat=c("f", "ser")
          )
```
\doublespace

The key takeaway from Table \@ref(tab:regression8) is that including the dummy for the 2004 Election, as predicted, absorbs quite a bit of the magnitude and statistical significance, again stemming from the correlation and multicollinearity that exists between the dependent variable and several of the independent variables in Table \@ref(tab:regression7). Most importantly, inclusion of the 2004 Election dummy, as shown in models 5 - 6, results in statistically insignificant coefficients on instances of a violation of one of the central principles and the interaction term between violation and polarization. 

## Additional Figures 

This section of the Appendix features several additional graphs that help descriptively present the data.  

Figure \@ref(fig:def-theme) displays for each election cycle the number of national security-themed ads, the number of ads that contain some form of military imagery, the number of non-national security themed ads, and the total number of advertisements. Although these statistics do not reflect challenges to the central principles of civil-military relations, they nonetheless provide a useful starting point regarding the general prominence of military and defense related issues during the five presidential elections from 2000 - 2016.

```{r def-theme, include=TRUE, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Presidential Campaign Advertisements Featuring Military Imagery, Separated by Ads that are Entirely Focused on National Security Topics", fig.height=4, fig.width=7}

plots_data <- adj_df %>% select(year, Yrcount, sum_mil_img_cycle, sum_no_mil_img_cycle, sum_def_vet_ad_theme, sum_non_def_vet_ad_theme, sum_def_theme_and_mil_img, sum_not_def_theme_but_mil_img) %>% view()

# now send this data frame to the pivot_longer function to make it more easily graphable
# use the distinct () function to keep only pertinent values
 graph_plot1_data <- plots_data %>% select(year, Yrcount, sum_def_vet_ad_theme, sum_non_def_vet_ad_theme, sum_mil_img_cycle) %>% pivot_longer(Yrcount:sum_mil_img_cycle, names_to = "statistic", values_to = "Number") %>% distinct () %>% view ()

plot1 <- ggplot(data=graph_plot1_data, aes(fill=statistic, x=year, y=Number)) + geom_bar(position="dodge", stat="identity") + labs(x="Election", y="Number of Presidential Campaign Ads") + scale_fill_discrete(name="Value",
                         breaks=c("sum_def_vet_ad_theme", "sum_mil_img_cycle", "sum_non_def_vet_ad_theme", "Yrcount"),
                         labels=c("National Security-Themed Ads", "Ads that Featured Some Form of Military Imagery", "Non-National Security Themed Ads", "Total Number of Ads")) + theme(legend.position="bottom")

plot1 

```

## To What Extent Is the Military an Enduring Campaign Issue?  

It is worth examining the degree to which the military stands out in a general sense in campaign advertisements over time. In other words, while exogenous events such as wars and international crises are likely to drive changes in the agendas of political candidates, and thus, changes in national security-themed campaign advertisements that feature the military, there might also be some baseline level of attention that the military receives from political candidates that is separate from wars or prominent international crises in which the military plays a noteworthy role.

Figure \@ref(fig:mil-img) below displays the number of non-national security related advertisements in each election cycle that feature some form of military imagery. In these campaign advertisements, therefore, there were themes presented other than those that focus entirely on issues of national security, defense, or veterans issues, but military imagery nonetheless appeared in the advertisement. Of all of the various non-security related issues and themes that are raised during a campaign advertisement, the military nonetheless made the cut. 

```{r mil-img, warning=FALSE, error=FALSE, include=TRUE, echo=FALSE, fig.height=4, fig.width=6, fig.cap= "Non-National Security Themed Campaign Ads that Featured Military Imagery"}

graph_plot2_data <- plots_data %>% select(year, sum_not_def_theme_but_mil_img, sum_non_def_vet_ad_theme) %>% pivot_longer(sum_not_def_theme_but_mil_img:sum_non_def_vet_ad_theme, names_to = "statistic", values_to = "Number") %>% distinct () %>% view ()

plot2 <- ggplot(data=graph_plot2_data, aes(fill=statistic, x=year, y=Number)) + geom_bar(position="dodge", stat="identity") + labs(x="Election", y="Number of Presidential Campaign Ads") + scale_fill_discrete(name="Value",
                         breaks=c("sum_non_def_vet_ad_theme", "sum_not_def_theme_but_mil_img"),
                         labels=c("Non-National Security Themed Ads", "Non-National Security Themed Ads That Contained Military Imagery")) + theme(legend.position="bottom")

plot2

```

Note the relative consistency in the fact that from 2000 - 2016, military imagery featured in a healthy proportion of campaign advertisements that were not focused on issues of national security, defense, or veterans issues. These results suggest that at least for the past 20 years, American political candidates have conveyed to the public their desire to support and strengthen the military in a very general sense. Although the data examined do not extend far back enough in time to prove the following conclusion, a trend of political candidates appealing to the public by acknowledging and featuring the military - at least in a general way during campaign advertisements - reflects the relatively high level of military prestige that the US military has commanded since at least 2000.
